docs.lead_paragraph: O'SULLIVAN--Mary Ellen, 77, of Bronxville, New York passed away peacefully on March 6th, 2014. She is survived by her brother, Jack Baker and his wife Babs, her daughter, Maura O'Sullivan, and her granddaughter, Siobhan D'Angelo. She was born to William and Catherine Baker on April 30th, 1936 in Manhattan. She received a B.A. in English from the College of Mount St. Vincent in 1958 and pursued a master's degree in English at Hunter College. She was very active in her community, volunteering her time to many organizations such as Meals on Wheels and Pregnancy Care Center. Calling hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, on Monday, March 10th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made in her name to The Ursuline School or Pregnancy Care Center.

headline.main: To Change India's Preference for Sons, Start With the Women

docs.abstract: The author of “Gender Equality and Inequality in Rural India: Blessed With a Son” says her studies show that using education and employment to help girls get on an equal footing with sons would help reduce gender bias.
docs.snippet: The author of “Gender Equality and Inequality in Rural India: Blessed With a Son” says her studies show that using education and employment to help girls get on an equal footing with sons would help reduce gender bias.

docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion providers are suing the state to try to block new rules limiting the use of the most common abortion-inducing drugs.
docs.abstract: Abortion providers are suing state of Arizona to try to block new rules limiting the use of the most common abortion-inducing drugs.
docs.snippet: Abortion providers are suing the state to try to block new rules limiting the use of the most common abortion-inducing drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Another baby born with H.I.V. and treated with drugs shortly after birth is now 9 months old and apparently H.I.V.-negative. The success of the treatment raises hopes for a path to rid babies of the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: Early Treatment Is Found to Clear H.I.V. in a 2nd Baby
headline.print_headline: Early Treatment Found to Clear H.I.V. in 2nd Baby

docs.abstract: Researchers at the Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections reveal that a second baby has been apparently cured of HIV through aggressive drug treatment shortly after birth, leaving little doubt that treatment works; add that, if successful, clinical trial set to begin could remake protocol for treating all 250,000 babies born infected each year worldwide; announcement is latest hopeful news about virus that causes AIDS.
docs.snippet: Another baby born with H.I.V. and treated with drugs shortly after birth is now 9 months old and apparently H.I.V.-negative. The success of the treatment raises hopes for a path to rid babies of the virus that causes AIDS.

docs.lead_paragraph: A second baby born with the AIDS virus may have had her infection put into remission and possibly cured by very early treatment — in this instance, four hours after birth.

headline.main: Doctors Hope for Cure in a 2nd Baby Born With HIV
headline.print_headline: Doctors Hope for Cure in a 2nd Baby Born With HIV

docs.snippet: A second baby born with the AIDS virus may have had her infection put into remission and possibly cured by very early treatment — in this instance, four hours after birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: If an objective is to help poor children and young people achieve better lives, it may be time to stop trying to reshape families into a platonic ideal.

headline.main: Time to Try Compassion, Not Censure, for Families
headline.print_headline: Time to Try Compassion, Not Censure, for Families

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column praises Obama administration proposal to expand the earned-income tax credit to include workers who do not care for children, calling it a potential turning point in the battle against poverty; argues that 50-year effort to reshape poor families and punish absentee fathers has been a failure, and that stripping moral condemnation out of social policy is an essential step toward success.
docs.snippet: If an objective is to help poor children and young people achieve better lives, it may be time to stop trying to reshape families into a platonic ideal.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Alabama House of Representatives has approved several abortion restrictions, including one that bans them once a fetal heartbeat is detected.

headline.main: Alabama House Approves Fetal Heartbeat Bill
headline.print_headline: Alabama House Approves Fetal Heartbeat Bill

docs.snippet: The Alabama House of Representatives has approved several abortion restrictions, including one that bans them once a fetal heartbeat is detected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alabama lawmakers on Tuesday approved a bill that would ban abortions after a fetal heartbeat is heard, which will almost guarantee a legal challenge from opponents.

headline.main: Alabama Lawmakers Weigh Strict 'Fetal Heartbeat' Abortion Ban
headline.print_headline: Alabama Lawmakers Weigh Strict 'Fetal Heartbeat' Abortion Ban

docs.snippet: Alabama lawmakers on Tuesday approved a bill that would ban abortions after a fetal heartbeat is heard, which will almost guarantee a legal challenge from opponents.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study showed that in selecting mates, male dragon lizards preferred females with orange patches on their underbellies, a sign that they were fertile.

headline.main: How a Lizard Gets Rid of a Suitor
headline.print_headline: Reptiles: How a Lizard Gets Rid of a Suitor

docs.abstract: Devi Stuart-Fox and Jennifer Goode study in journal Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution finds that intensity of orange patches on female dragon lizards in Australia, developed when lizards are fertile, attract male lizards searching for mates.
docs.snippet: A study showed that in selecting mates, male dragon lizards preferred females with orange patches on their underbellies, a sign that they were fertile.
